payload.instructions:
Unified Agent Guidelines for Modern Swift & SwiftUI Work

Platform & Project Targets

Target iOS 26+ and macOS 26+. Assume the newest APIs are available and avoid anything deprecated. Prefer folder references in Xcode so new files are automatically tracked.

Swift Concurrency

Structured concurrency is the law of the land. Use async/await, Task, and actors. Don’t use GCD (DispatchQueue.*) unless something truly forces your hand. Avoid legacy completion handlers when a modern API exists.

Task.sleep(for:) replaces Task.sleep(nanoseconds:).

Everything that touches UI or shared state: prefer @MainActor.

Swift Language Style

Use the newest Foundation and Swift conveniences:
	•	Prefer URL.documentsDirectory and appending(path:).
	•	Prefer String.replacing(...) over older Foundation string APIs.
	•	Avoid force unwraps and force tries unless unrecoverable.
	•	Use static member syntax when Swift allows (.circle, .borderedProminent).

Pluralization uses Swift’s inflection syntax:

Text("Missing ^[\(missingCount) part](inflect: true)")

Never hand-roll "part" vs "parts" again.

SwiftUI Best Practices

SwiftUI evolves fast; lean into its modern shape:
	•	Use foregroundStyle() instead of foregroundColor().
	•	Use clipShape(.rect(cornerRadius:)) instead of cornerRadius().
	•	Prefer Tab over older tabItem().
	•	Use NavigationStack and navigationDestination(for:) for navigation.
	•	Always choose Button over gesture recognizers unless tap metadata matters.
	•	Avoid GeometryReader when containerRelativeFrame() or newer layout tools work.
	•	Indicators off? Use .scrollIndicators(.hidden).
	•	If rendering a SwiftUI view to an image: use ImageRenderer.
	•	Use Button("Text", systemImage: "...") instead of image-only buttons.
	•	Keep views simple—extract subviews instead of using bulky computed properties.
	•	Avoid hard-coding padding, spacing, and font sizes unless explicitly required.
	•	Prefer Dynamic Type over fixed fonts.
	•	Never rely on UIScreen.main.bounds.

Observable State
Use @Observable types instead of ObservableObject, and mark them @MainActor.

Text Filtering
Use localizedStandardContains() for anything involving user input.

SwiftData Guidelines

When using SwiftData with CloudKit:
	•	Don’t use @Attribute(.unique).
	•	Model properties must be optional or have default values.
	•	All relationships must be optional.

Testing Philosophy

Swift Testing is the testing framework. XCTest is officially retired here.

Use:
	•	swift test for frameworks and logic,
	•	swift test --filter to focus on a test suite or case,
	•	#expect for normal assertions,
	•	#require when the test cannot continue without a value.

Integration tests should guard on API availability with .enabled(if: …).

For SwiftUI targets, build with xcodebuild and the iOS 26 simulator.

Add -showBuildTimingSummary when triaging build speed; otherwise keep logs quiet.

LLM & AgentCorp (Where Relevant)

If you’re in AgentCorp-land:
	•	All LLM interactions must go through the AgentCorp framework.
	•	macOS clients must use SwiftUI’s SettingsLink.
	•	When running analyzers, ensure Google/OpenAI keys exist in APIKeyStore.
	•	Use the Files API (uploadImage) for image-based before/after analysis.

⸻

Core Wisdom Across All These Files

Modern Swift is pushing toward:
	•	Strong type safety.
	•	Structured concurrency everywhere.
	•	SwiftUI as the default UI layer.
	•	Swift Testing instead of XCTest.
	•	Declarative patterns over imperative patterns.
	•	Avoiding legacy APIs unless absolutely unavoidable.

The overarching message: build for the future, not the past. Lean into Swift’s new features early so your code ages gracefully rather than painfully.


## Skills
These skills are discovered at startup from multiple local sources. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions.
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/oliver/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/oliver/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
- Discovery: Available skills are listed in project docs and may also appear in a runtime "## Skills" section (name + description + file path). These are the sources of truth; skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Description as trigger: The YAML `description` in `SKILL.md` is the primary trigger signal; rely on it to decide applicability. If unsure, ask a brief clarification before proceeding.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deeply nested references; prefer one-hop files explicitly linked from `SKILL.md`.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# AGENTS.md instructions for /Users/oliver/Developer/ICS/AICS

<INSTRUCTIONS>
Unified Agent Guidelines for Modern Swift & SwiftUI Work

Platform & Project Targets

Target iOS 26+ and macOS 26+. Assume the newest APIs are available and avoid anything deprecated. Prefer folder references in Xcode so new files are automatically tracked.

Swift Concurrency

Structured concurrency is the law of the land. Use async/await, Task, and actors. Don’t use GCD (DispatchQueue.*) unless something truly forces your hand. Avoid legacy completion handlers when a modern API exists.

Task.sleep(for:) replaces Task.sleep(nanoseconds:).

Everything that touches UI or shared state: prefer @MainActor.

Swift Language Style

Use the newest Foundation and Swift conveniences:
	•	Prefer URL.documentsDirectory and appending(path:).
	•	Prefer String.replacing(...) over older Foundation string APIs.
	•	Avoid force unwraps and force tries unless unrecoverable.
	•	Use static member syntax when Swift allows (.circle, .borderedProminent).

Pluralization uses Swift’s inflection syntax:

Text("Missing ^[\(missingCount) part](inflect: true)")

Never hand-roll "part" vs "parts" again.

SwiftUI Best Practices

SwiftUI evolves fast; lean into its modern shape:
	•	Use foregroundStyle() instead of foregroundColor().
	•	Use clipShape(.rect(cornerRadius:)) instead of cornerRadius().
	•	Prefer Tab over older tabItem().
	•	Use NavigationStack and navigationDestination(for:) for navigation.
	•	Always choose Button over gesture recognizers unless tap metadata matters.

	•	Indicators off? Use .scrollIndicators(.hidden).
	•	If rendering a SwiftUI view to an image: use ImageRenderer.

	•	Keep views simple—extract subviews instead of using bulky computed properties.

	•	Prefer Dynamic Type over fixed fonts.
	•	Never rely on UIScreen.main.bounds.

Observable State
Use @Observable types instead of ObservableObject, and mark them @MainActor.

Use localizedStandardContains() for anything involving user input.

SwiftData Guidelines

When using SwiftData with CloudKit:
	•	Don’t use @Attribute(.unique).
	•	Model properties must be optional or have default values.
	•	All relationships must be optional.

Testing Philosophy

Swift Testing is the testing framework. XCTest is officially retired here.

Use:
	•	swift test for frameworks and logic,

	•	#expect for normal assertions,
	•	#require when the test cannot continue without a value.

Integration tests should guard on API availability with .enabled(if: …).

For SwiftUI targets, build with xcodebuild and the iOS 26 simulator.

Add -showBuildTimingSummary when triaging build speed; otherwise keep logs quiet.

LLM & AgentCorp (Where Relevant)

If you’re in AgentCorp-land:
	•	All LLM interactions must go through the AgentCorp framework.
	•	macOS clients must use SwiftUI’s SettingsLink.
	•	When running analyzers, ensure Google/OpenAI keys exist in APIKeyStore.
	•	Use the Files API (uploadImage) for image-based before/after analysis.

⸻

Core Wisdom Across All These Files

Modern Swift is pushing toward:
	•	Strong type safety.
	•	Structured concurrency everywhere.
	•	SwiftUI as the default UI layer.
	•	Swift Testing instead of XCTest.
	•	Declarative patterns over imperative patterns.
	•	Avoiding legacy APIs unless absolutely unavoidable.

The overarching message: build for the future, not the past. Lean into Swift’s new features early so your code ages gracefully rather than painfully.

# Context from my IDE setup:

## Active file: App/EditorApp/Sources/EditorView.swift

## Open tabs:
- EditorView.swift: App/EditorApp/Sources/EditorView.swift

## My request for Codex:
Add double-click to zoom in and out on image, and drag around with hand cursor, same as we have in Proofics.
